Feynman hated jargon because it got in the way of actually understanding things. In my estimation, trying to keep things like "extrinsic line" or "Arc length" straight is not widely possible. I'd recommend next time breaking down what these things are, and just labeling them differently (More simply) so that it is easier to track. It was fairly common for Feynman to use words and phrases like "Whatever" and "It doesn't matter" in his explanations of complex theories, because he was trying to strip down as much complexity as possible from getting in the way of his audience understanding what he was saying.

In this regard, I feel like this was much harder to follow than it had to be.

while the presentation here is likely completely accurate, the presenter's pace is quick, and as I compared it to the clip of feynman talking it seems evident that feynman had a better grasp of how to present the idea. Feynman is a rich history but one thing is clear he could talk about any subject and pull out relationships you are not likely to have oriented to via your education. He was fairly unique in learning approach and ability to describe. The tone here with this particular person's take on it is far too scripted. And while it may be true that all the explanations provided are correct, they would be more effective if you had presented the full complexity of the question in feynman's terms first and then attach your bits at relevant proof points if you will. you dive first into a sort of maze of graphics and rapid fire explanations never having anchored the viewer to something solid to track with in the first place. Read any of Feynman's books from Surely You're Joking, Mr. Feynman to the 3 volume set of cal tech lectures or the cornell lecture vids and he will present such an anchor and then reinforce that idea repeatedly. that is the connection you need to have in this to really allow the graphics and your too fast explanations to be truly valuable in education.
Just my opinion.

If we were in the 6th dimension, we would be able to travel in time in these twins worlds. If we were in the 7th, we would be travel to all parallel words no matther the initial conditions. (1) As a professional fan of 3Blue1Brown educational resource, I must say he outdid himself in this video! Visualizing without trivializing, Grant is using a heavier proportion of geometry (as Principia does, a nod to Ancient Greek mathematics, inherited by Roman engineers; no wonder Newton's Principia is in Classical Latin) while still staying faithful to the contemporary approach by relying on the titular Feynman's lecture. Do not hesitate to recommend it to your own child or sibling if you have a high-schooler. It is a most unexpected to see things done correctly in our just do it, whatever age. "Quality" is the first word to come to mind.


(2) As rigorous "algebraic" thinking calculus-based multiple formulae must accompany this to be internalized fully, help your youngster through this.


(3) On the linguistic side of things I noticed [PrinKipia] pronunciation of Principia rather than [PrinTZipia] or [PrinSipia], which is how it is done indeed in the modern American English, as oppose to the traditional and more Latinized sounding out.


(4) Surprisingly accurate usage of Physics terminology! One could always nitpick further, but here I would not: a perfect balance of accuracy and clarity is achieved.

I have had a particular fondness for this proof because some years ago I discovered for myself one of the key steps and was amazed to see the role it played in Feynman's proof.  My discovery started with a paper-folding construction of a parabola: mark a point on a page and fold points from the edge to that point.  The creases are an envelope for a parabola.  I then set out to find similar constructions for ellipses and hyperbolas.  For the ellipse, start with a circular disk of paper and an off-centered point.  Fold each point on the edge to the point and the creases form an envelope of the ellipse.  I think this is a more elegant statement of the step of rotating the radial line segments at their midpoints, but it is equivalent.  By the way, the paper folding constructions can be used to prove the reflection properties of all three conics too.

The Great Physicists' Road Trip by Ms. Rachel C. Millison

Great physicists from the past decide to return to Earth for one last road-trip vacation to the coast together. They all appear on Earth on the appointed evening. Heisenberg pulls up behind the wheel of a gigantic 1930's car, a huge grin on his face.
As they're getting in the car, Hubble looks up and says "What a wonderfully dark sky".
"Shouldn't be" responds Olbers.
"Always has been" says Hoyle.
"No, it hasn't" says Lemaitre.
"I knew that!" says an embarrassed Einstein.
Once they're all in, Teller says "Hey guys, this trip is going to be The Bomb!".
"Yeah, but why do I always have to organize?" asks Oppenheimer.
"Where exactly will we end up?" asks Kepler.
"That's impossible to predict" says Bohr.
"I just can't believe that's true" says Einstein.
Heisenberg punches the throttle and the old car roars off.
"Say - this thing sure accelerates" says Newton.
"I don't know, Isaac. It feels like gravity to me" smirks Einstein.

Later that night, as they are speeding down a country road, a police car catches up to them and pulls them over.[1]
"Do you know how fast you were going?" the cop asks. [1]
"No, but I know exactly where I am" Heisenberg replies. [1]
The cop says "You were doing 55 in a 35" [1]
Heisenberg throws up his hands and shouts "Great! Now I'm lost!" [1]
The cop thinks this is suspicious and orders him to pop open the trunk. He checks it out and says "Do you know you have a dead cat back here?" [1]
"We do now, asshole!" shouts Schrodinger. [1]
"I think it's time to split" says Everett.

"Say, how did you manage to spot us on such a dark night?" asks Hubble.
"I saw the light from your head lamps" says the cop.
"How fast was it going?" asks Michelson.
"That's simple addition" giggles Galileo.
"Not exactly" says Lorentz.
"Look here" says Heisenberg, "how do you know I was going that fast?"
"I clocked you over a measured distance" says the cop.
"How often?" asks Hertz.
"I disagree with your measurement, officer" interjects Einstein.
"Don't start tonight, Albert" says Bohr, shaking his head.
"What Herr Einstein is trying to say" continues Heisenberg, "is that time was running at a different rate for you than for us".
"WHAT!!!???" exclaims Newton.
"It's true" says Maxwell. "We're all famous scientists and, believe us, Herr Einstein has proved it, though it came as no surprise to me".
"Sounds complicated" responds the cop.
"I'll draw you a simple diagram" says Feynman.
Totally flummoxed, the cop lets them go with a warning. As he drives away, Doppler cocks his head and listens to the sound of the receding police car. "Gotta love that" he says.
"Amen" responds Hubble.

Returning to their car, Lord Kelvin remarks "Sure is warm tonight"
"Yep - lots of disorder" replies Boltzmann.
"In places you'd never expect" adds Hawking.
"I was lucky to get away with that" says Heisenberg. "Most cops think they're better than everyone else".
"Yes - I hate inequality" adds Bell.
"Though you were speeding" says Faraday to Heisenberg. "I carefully observed the needle creep from 35 to 55".
"Actually, it was jumping, Michael" replies Planck.

As they pile back into the car, Bohr says "See here - you must fill the seats in order - no empty spaces allowed. And stop interfering with each other!"
"Only one of you can sit next to me!" yells an agitated Pauli.
"Say, Werner - it's stuffy in here. Be a good chap and crack the window a bit" says Hawking.
"Sorry, Stephen. It can be all the way up or all the way down, but nowhere in between" replies Heisenberg.
"Hey guys - Albert and I just figured out a great shortcut. Only one bridge" announces Rosen.
"It will save us a lot of distance" says Einstein, "but it might get spooky".

Arriving at the beach the next morning, they hurry from the car and stand looking out over the ocean.
"Look at the wonderful waves" says Schrodinger.
"They don't look like waves to me" says Bohr.
Looking down at the fine sand, Dirac exclaims "Look at all the particles!"
"Now those look like waves" says De Broglie.
"This is great!" exclaims Feynman, rubbing his hands together. "Now, lets go meet some girls!"
"Let's delay" says Wheeler.
"We have to be discrete" warns Bohm.
"Girls? NEVER!" exclaims Newton.

Newton started off with a bet to prove this (the ellipse being a consequence of the inverse square law) and produced a series of publications, eventually compiling the principia mathematica out of this seed. However, although he never states this clearly, I'm sure he realized that the proof he gave was for the converse: that given an elliptic orbit, an inverse square force law follows. This was much easier at the time because so much was known about the geometric properties of the ellipse than was about F=m a. In fact, Newton couldn't really mathematically use velocities because they compare two quantities with unequal units (distance, time). Also of course algebraic notations and vectors weren't invented yet. But still Newton claimed to have won his bet, and the Principia avoids any clarity about proving the inverse square law vs. the converse (proving the elliptic shape).
I'm sure Newton would have LOVED this type of proof, and this proof in particular! Although I'm sure he'd appreciate how much more powerful modern mathematical notation and ideas such as vector or Lagrangian calculus are. And that's where Feynman and 3blue1brown comes in: Elementary proofs just are the next level of understanding: being able to explain something seemingly complicated in simple terms. With intuitive concepts, but with methods not more complicated that what was available to Newton.

This should be proof that orbits (2 bodies only) are all conics.
The circle is a special case of the ellipse. (Duh)
The parabola would emerge if the excentric-point is on the circle.
In this case the diameter of the circle would be the escape-velocity of the orbit with a given periapsis, and the velocity would become 0 once the distance reaches infinity.

The hyperbola would emerge if the excentric-point is outside the circle.
In the case of the hyperbola, the tangents to the circle, that pass through the excentric-point, would be the boundaries between the velocity vectors that correspond to the two halfes of the hyperbola.
The far side of the circle would correspond to the velocity vectors of an object going faster than escape-velocity in an attractive field, and the near-side would correspond to the velocity vectors of an object in a repulsive field, e.g. proton scattering.

The earth could revolve around the sun in a circle under a very specific initial condition, namely if its instantaneous velocity is perpendicular to the radial vector of the its distance from the sun. Meanwhile, I've tried hard to acquaint myself with every existing variety of fields in which the highest math skills are put to work. I've gotten some great books from the library, and have devoured countless, thrilling stories of the history of science. Showing that the change in velocity over the same area is constant can actually actually be done much easier. What you are looking for is dv/dA. We know that dv/dt = a (Newtons second law). Also, we know that dA/dt = const (Keplers second law). So, dv/dA = (dv/dt)/(dA/dt) = a/c = const.

Relating the unknown [the ellipse] to a well known [the circle], is a process of seeding that effectively adds a 2nd deck of cards.
It inserts a wedge between some related variables & adds relations to other known ones.
Its the same problem we face when we have 2 eqns & 3 unknowns.
Additional relations must be added.
From there we follow the questions that arise while always having the target in focus.
In this case here, Feynman added a twist of sorcery, at a crucial point of discovery he retraced his initial steps endeavoring to find a problem that yields his solution.
The genius makes a crucial stop, backs up & asks how did I get here, answering that question reveals the dynamics of going from a to b, inside the new problem he has created.

Don't feel bad if you are having a hard time understanding this. Keplerian physics from first principals is very difficult. The first time you really are brutalized by it is as a first-year physics graduate student. As a grad student, you are required to be able to derive Kepler's laws on the fly and do so during a test; I was required to do it at any rate. By the way, if you think the geometric proof is bad, try the analytic. You end up with something that is, not surprisingly, called an elliptic integral. Most elliptic integrals do not have closed solutions. It just so happens that the one for Keplerian motion, i.e. an inverse square law, is solvable. However, as far as solvable integrals go it is a worst case scenario that is going to take like 10 pages of various substitutions and every other dirty trick in your anti-differentiation arsenal including trig sub. I still have nightmares.

Besides elliptical orbits not really requiring the inverse square law, Feynman also mentions that gravity is not intrinsically an inverse square law. Elliptical orbits result from any centrally directed force. The force doesn't have to vary inversely as the square.

Feynman figured out what the force of gravity would be for a plane of constant thickness stretching to infinity. (Instead of limited and spherical.) The force of gravity would then be constant regardless of the distance from the plane. In other words, the apparent law of gravity is really due to the shape and finiteness of masses. That is, it is the result of geometry.

More well known is the peculiarity that the force of gravity is zero everywhere inside a spherical shell of constant thickness. And everywhere outside of the sphere, the force is equivalent to some mass located at its center. Gravity becomes less underground, and is zero at the center of the Earth.

Newton concealed what became known as calculus (and the fact that he used it) until long after the Principia was published. (Calculus was tacked onto the end of a later book not on gravity.) Instead he gave geometry style demonstrations, similar to the ancient Greeks, a form which Newton thought was better by far.

Principia was published in Latin. (Newton's early education was in Latin.) According to people that know Latin, the Latin in Principia is practically incomprehensible. And the approach was also alien to what a normal physicist (a natural philosopher) of the time would know. The first readers only knew that the man had to be some kind of genius to be that difficult. (Newton actually said he changed his mind from at first making it simple to making it difficult.) If Feynman gave up deciphering the original, raw Newton version, he was following in the footsteps of many.

I figured it out on 6:26. All planets orbit their barycenter, and the star orbits all the planet's barycenters. Here's a easier way to understand the lecture: Think of a circle. The circle is the orbit, and there's a planet on it. Now, put a center in the orbit. Then, add the star on the other side of the center. This forms two circles, one of which is the star's circle. The center we put in the orbit becomes the barycenter, and since both objects (star and planet) are equal distance from the barycenter. So move the planet along the orbit. Stars do not move around the barycenter because they are not of equal mass. Instead, make the sun constantly rotate, facing the planet always. Here you'll now see a ellipse orbit forming.

Once you've established the necessary properties of the orbital curve described at 18:29, there's actually another very different argument that will also show that an ellipse is the right curve. First, realize that the angle theta shown in the velocity space is offset by 90 degrees from the angle on the orbital diagram. The move at 18:52 then amounts to simply re-aligning these mismatched thetas, and then pointing the velocity vectors back in the right direction. Restoring the proper positions of the velocity vectors in a way that precisely mimics the construction of an ellipse shows that the orbital path must be an ellipse.

However, we haven't proven that the velocity-space theta and the orbital theta actually are offset by 90 degrees. It looks reasonable, and for some special vectors it's easy to show, but an actual proof would be very nice. To see why it is, consider the acceleration vectors (the little yellow ones that form the boundary of the velocity-space circle). They are all of equal length and are all aimed at a common point. Their orientations relative to one another are the same as those of the radii of a circle. However, in the velocity-space diagram, the acceleration vectors have the same orientation, but they are tangents of the circle, not radii. Because the radius of a circle is perpendicular to the tangent line at the point the radius meets the circumference, we can conclude that the tangent of a circle parallel to a given radius is 90 degrees away from that radius. This means that in order to be rearranged from being radii to being tangents while maintaining orientation, each acceleration vector must have been offset by 90 degrees.

Now that we know for certain that the angles in the velocity-space are offset by 90 degrees from the actual orbit, it's clear that the elliptical construction at 18:52 is simply returning the velocity vectors to their rightful places, indicating that the shape of the orbit is elliptical.

If the ending was unclear, here is an attempt to break it down into smaller steps: 1. the tangent to the orbit is parallel to the velocity (by definition), 2. the velocity when the object has traversed a certain angle is perpendicular to the 90-degree-rotated velocity of the one obtained from traversing the circle by that same angle (it obviously does not matter which perpendicular line is chosen here, since we're just talking about direction) 3. one particular perpendicular is the perpendicular bisector, so the orbit's tangent is parallel to the perpendicular bisector obtained at that angle 4. these perpendicular bisectors are tangent to an ellipse (in the velocity diagram) at a certain point, so the orbit's tangent is parallel to the ellipse's tangents at those points 5. that tangent point on the velocity-diagram-ellipse is along the radial line used to chose the velocity to begin with, 6. again this radial line is presumed to be along the same angle as what the orbit is currently at, and finally 7. the orbit's tangent is therefore parallel to the ellipse's tangent along every angle (with respect to one of the foci)
That's a pretty normal way of constructing an ellipse!
